Finding B: With whey pre-load, insulin and GLP-1 responses also were significantly higher (105 and 141 percent, respectively), producing a 96 percent increase in early insulin response.

Biology_tweet_24_r$Biology_422_r$Biology.text:
Finding A: interesting read on how gut bacteria are different between two countries which are both rural. this could be due to their culture that made for these differences. #BS3017
Finding B: Then the team identified 27 unique bacterial features unique to the gut microbiomes, and thus stool, of people with NAFLD-cirrhosis.
Finding C: Furthermore, coevolved ciliates had a significantly higher growth rate compared to the ancestral ciliates at a given coevolved bacteria population ( Fig.
Finding D: Our data (1) confirm excess burden of genome-wide rare genic CNVs in an independent set of ASD subjects versus control subjects; (2) further reveal an extreme degree of etiological heterogeneity (36 different genetic loci were found among 82 individuals with pathogenic CNVs); (3) confirm the contribution of de novo CNVs to the etiology of autism and highlight the contribution of inherited pathogenic imbalances (36%); (4) show an increased proportion of females among carriers of highly penetrant pathogenic CNVs, as well as among carriers of deletions affecting FMRP targets; show no significant difference in the frequency of de novo CNVs between simplex and multiplex families; show that both deletions and duplications involving FMRP targets and PSD genes increase ASD risk; (7) show evidence of multigene contributions to ASD; show that ASD-associated deletions impair synapse function and neurodevelopmental processes; (9) implicate chromatin and transcription regulation genes in ASD in a network analysis of de novo CNVs; and show that genes affected by de novo CNVs and de novo LoF SNVs converge on functional gene networks.

Finding C: Furthermore, coevolved ciliates had a significantly higher growth rate compared to the ancestral ciliates at a given coevolved bacteria population ( Fig.
Finding D: Our data (1) confirm excess burden of genome-wide rare genic CNVs in an independent set of ASD subjects versus control subjects; (2) further reveal an extreme degree of etiological heterogeneity (36 different genetic loci were found among 82 individuals with pathogenic CNVs); (3) confirm the contribution of de novo CNVs to the etiology of autism and highlight the contribution of inherited pathogenic imbalances (36%); (4) show an increased proportion of females among carriers of highly penetrant pathogenic CNVs, as well as among carriers of deletions affecting FMRP targets; show no significant difference in the frequency of de novo CNVs between simplex and multiplex families; show that both deletions and duplications involving FMRP targets and PSD genes increase ASD risk; (7) show evidence of multigene contributions to ASD; show that ASD-associated deletions impair synapse function and neurodevelopmental processes; (9) implicate chromatin and transcription regulation genes in ASD in a network analysis of de novo CNVs; and show that genes affected by de novo CNVs and de novo LoF SNVs converge on functional gene networks.
